title: How long until the vegan trend stops? - Quora

response.answer_text: One of the biggest misconceptions of veganism is that it is a diet. I am not sure if this is implied in your question, but when people refer to veganism as a trend this tends to be one of the underlying perceptions. From the Vegan Society: Veganism is a way of living which seeks to exclude, as far as is possible and practicable, all forms of exploitation of, and cruelty to, animals for food, clothing or any other purpose.[1] I prefer to frame veganism as the principle of not harming (including killing) sentient beings. As you can see from both of our definitions, veganism boils down to not exploiting sentient beings, namely animals, for any purpose. These definitions therefore stretch veganism beyond being just a diet. And the reasons for becoming vegan are many and can usually be characterized under ethical, environmental and health reasons. Because of this, in practice, I do not foresee veganism slowing down anytime soon. In fact, there are straightforward data that show veganism is rising. That does not mean it cannot end, but it does mean more and more people are catching on to the fact that we can live healthy, prosperous lives without contributing to the harm and death of other sentient beings. But your question is asking when will it potentially end and when that will be. I foresee it ending when we no longer breed and slaughter animals for food, clothing or any other use. It will have ended because veganism will be the social norm and therefore will no longer need a label. I do not see this happening in this lifetime but perhaps within the next few hundred years or so. Footnotes[1] Definition of veganism

Well, if the vegan ‘trend’ stops, we may as well say goodbye to our planet. Animal agriculture is the most destructive industry on earth today. Some of the scientific studies and projections are just alarming… Researchers Say Only Way to Guarantee Enough Food in 2050 Is if the World Turns Vegan Oceans' Fish Could Disappear by 2050 STUDY: 60 Percent of Global Biodiversity Loss Caused by Meat  Given the health benefits of a vegan diet and how much money it is going to save our healthcare systems worldwide, not to mention eliminate animal cruelty in our factory farms, there is really no good reason for people not to change to the better diet. You can read more about the various benefits here, including links to many scientific studies:Helen Tam-Semmens's answer to Is it possible for vegetarians to make a truthful, convincing, and non-hypocritical argument against meat eating?
